author: @maxon5153
text: Hey guys, working code here!           import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np import urllib import urllib.request import matplotlib.dates as mdates from matplotlib.dates import bytespdate2num  def graph_data():      stock_price_url = 'https://pythonprogramming.net/yahoo_finance_replacement'      source_code = urllib.request.urlopen(stock_price_url).read().decode()      stock_data = []      split_source = source_code.split('\n')      for line in split_source:         if "Date" not in line:             stock_data.append(line)            Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Adjusted_close, Volume = np.loadtxt(stock_data,                                                                         delimiter=",",                                                                         unpack=True,                                                                         converters={0:bytespdate2num('%Y-%m-%d', encoding='utf-8')})       plt.plot_date(Date, High, '-', label="Hahhaah")     plt.xlabel('Date')     plt.ylabel('Price')     plt.title('Working finally!')     plt.legend()     plt.show()  graph_data()

author: @miniboo4811
text: I tried so hard but finally worked ^^  I hope it'll help you too.   import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import numpy as np import pandas as pd import urllib import matplotlib.dates as mdates     def bytespdate2num(fmt, encoding='utf-8'):     strconverter = mdates.strpdate2num(fmt)     def bytesconverter(b):         s = b.decode(encoding)         return strconverter(s)     return bytesconverter   stock_price_url = 'https://pythonprogramming.net/yahoo_finance_replacement'   source_code = urllib.request.urlopen(stock_price_url).read().decode()    stock_data = [] split_source = source_code.split('\n')   for line in split_source[1:]:     stock_data.append(line)          Date, Open, High, Low, Close, Adjusted_Close, Volume = np.loadtxt(stock_data, delimiter=',',unpack=True, converters={0: bytespdate2num('%Y-%m-%d')})   plt.plot_date(Date, Open, '-', label='price') plt.xlabel('Date') plt.ylabel('Price') plt.title('Yeah finally!') plt.legend() plt.show()

text: If you struggle with this part of the Series try this code(Python 3.7):  def graph_data():     # new link from part 8(comments)     stock_price_url = 'https://pythonprogramming.net/yahoo_finance_replacement'     source_code = urllib.request.urlopen(stock_price_url).read().decode()          # or just use []     stock_data = list()     split_source = source_code.split('\n')     # [1:] because first row is headers     split_source = split_source[1:]     # just append data to empty list     for line in split_source:         stock_data.append(line)          # on the new data there is one more column     date, openp, higp, lowp, closep, adj_close, volume = np.loadtxt(stock_data,                                                          delimiter=',',                                                          unpack=True,                                                          # you don't need to write bytespdate2num by yourself                                                          converters={0: mdates.bytespdate2num('%Y-%m-%d')}      )     plt.plot_date(date, closep)      plt.xlabel('date')     plt.ylabel('Price')     plt.title('My graph')     plt.legend()     plt.show()

author: @jesusborruel6936
text: Your tutorials are awesome, thanks.  If you download data with: stock_price_url= 'https://pythonprogramming.net/yahoo_finance_replacement' or from yahoo finance (at least in 2018):  first file line is the column names, so to take it out, instead of: for line in split_source[ ]: should be: for line in split_source[1:]:  Also the columns downloaded include a new column 'Adj Close'. Instead of: if len(split_line)==6: should be: if len(split_line)==7:  And last, to be coherent with this changes, instead of:  date, openp, highp, lowp, closep, volume = np.loadtxt(stock_data,                                                         delimiter=',',                                                         unpack=True,                                                          converters={0: bytespdate2num('%Y-%m-%d')})  Should be:  date, openp, highp, lowp, closep, adjclosep, volume = np.loadtxt(stock_data,                                                         delimiter=',',                                                         unpack=True,                                                         converters={0: bytespdate2num('%Y-%m-%d')})  Greetings from Spain!!

text: For those who are getting this error 'urllib.error.URLError: <urlopen error [SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed (_ssl.c:777)>' use the following code      import requests     from bs4 import BeautifulSoup  'and instead of -> source_code = urllib.request.urlopen(stock_price_url).read().decode() '  write the following codes     page = requests.get(stock_price_url)     soup = BeautifulSoup(page.content, 'html.parser')     source_code = soup.prettify(encoding='utf-8').decode()

author: @vhoramuiz
text: @sentdex: Your code seems a lot complicated. I tried a simpler version from your another tutorial, which seems to work just fine and is a way more easier to understand and implement. Have a look here:  from pandas_datareader import data, wb  import datetime start = datetime.datetime(2010, 1, 1) end = datetime.datetime(2016, 1, 1) df = data.DataReader('TSLA', 'yahoo', start, end) df.reset_index(inplace = True) plt.plot_date(df.Date, df.Close, '-') plt.show()  That's it! It worked on a Jupyter notebook using Python 3 kernel, without the decoding function.  Your expert comments are highly welcomed! :P

author: @francoispaulsen2642
text: if you are using the url 'https://pythonprogramming.net/yahoo_finance_replacement' that was provided because the the Yahoo finance API does not work anymore then there are a couple of change that need to be made to make the code work.  if len(split_line) == 7     (it must be 7 because there is a new column of data that was added)     if 'Date' not in line:    (Values and Label can be removed and replace with 'Date' or just add it on in the line of code)  then in the line for np.loadtxt you need to add another variable and change the date format.  date, openp, highp, lowp, closep, adjclose, volume = np.loadtxt( .....         coverters={0: bytespdate2num('%Y-%m-%d')})     (just add dashes because the format is also different)  Then it should work, goodluck.

text: # pip install pandas_datareader import pandas_datareader import datetime start = datetime.datetime(2016, 1, 1) end = datetime.datetime(2017, 6, 13)  import pandas_datareader as pdr stock_data = pdr.get_data_google('AAPL')[start : end] plt.plot_date(stock_data['Close'].index,stock_data['Close'].values,'-', label='Price') plt.xlabel('Date') plt.ylabel('Price') plt.title('Interesting Graph\nCheck it out') plt.legend() plt.show()  This worked for me!

text: for python 2.x instead of bytespdate use following Days = np.loadtxt('exp1.txt',delimiter=',',unpack=True,dtype=str,usecols=(0),converters={0: lambda x: datetime.datetime.strptime(x,'%Y%m%d')}) Open,High,Low,Close,AdjClose,Volume=np.loadtxt('exp1.txt',delimiter=',',unpack=True,dtype=int,usecols=(1,2,3,4,5,6)) Dates=mdates.datestr2num(Days) plt.plot_date(Dates,Close)

author: @wimwds
text: It seems that Yahoo has discontinued its finance API  a couple of days ago :  https://forums.yahoo.net/t5/Yahoo-Finance-help/Is-Yahoo-Finance-API-broken/td-p/250503/page/3  Lets hope they can be persuaded to bring it back, but for the time being it doesn't look like it.   You can however download the data manually trough the yahoo finance website (historical data). (automating the download it a bit trickier due to their use of the -currently- undocumented 'crumb' parameter)

author: @runfunmc64
text: For anyone watching this now, it appears that Yahoo has started to use https instead of http so I followed the tutorial at this link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/27835619/ssl-certificate-verify-failed-error and it fixed the problem.  All you have to do is import ssl  and change       source_code = urllib.request.urlopen(stock_price_url).read().decode()  to     gcontext = ssl.SSLContext(ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1)     source_code = urllib.request.urlopen(stock_price_url, context = gcontext).read().decode()  then it will work.

author: @sahgerlad1528
text: Hi sentdex,  I enjoy your videos and am planning to go through most of them. I am currently having trouble understanding the bytes to string conversion you made. I have spent a long time reading the help for functions online and browsing the internet for answers but still do not have complete understanding of what is happening. My questions are:      1. How does numpy.loadtxt converters function work without actually inputting the list into the bytespdate2num function? The bytespdate2num function only inputs the date format, not the data itself.      2. The mdates.strpdate2num function does not have an input when I read the help, yet you input the date format. How does Python interpret this?      3. Within the bytespdate2num function you have the bytesconverter function with the input b. In the last line of bytespdate2num function you return the bytesconverter function without the function input. How does bytesconverter work without defining the input, b, in your return line?  Thank you for any information you can provide!
